arguments.claim: TPA s.54 governs transfers; Mohammedan law does not override

arguments.claim: Pre-emption right weak; can be defeated by legitimate means without fraud

anchor.surface_text: The right to pre-empt the sale is not exercisable till a pre-emptible transfer has been effected and the right of pre-emption is not one which is looked upon with great favour by the courts

arguments.claim: Courts do not favour pre-emption; no equities for pre-emptor

anchor.surface_text: The right of pre-emption is a weak right and is not looked upon with favour by courts and therefore the courts could not go out of their way to help the pre-emptor.

holdings.text: No right of pre-emption had accrued to respondent Sridhar under the provisions of the Code as there was no completed transfer by sale when the suit was filed.

anchor.surface_text: The first question for decision is whether a right of pre-emption had accrued to respondent Sridhar under the provisions of the Code. Previous to the cession of Berar by the Nizam of Hyderabad to the British Government in 1853, the Mohammedan rule of pre-emption was, according to one view, in force in the province of Berar and it continued to be so till the Berar Land Revenue Code of 1896 came into operation as from January 1, 1897.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-emption under Berar Code ss.174-184 requires completed transfer like registered sale; contracts of April 1943 did not pass title per TPA s.54.

holdings.text: The word 'sale' in s.176 of the Berar Code has the same connotation as under s.54 TPA and does not include mere contracts.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the word sale in s. 176 of the Code had a wider connotation than what it had under s. 54 of the Transfer of Property Act. That was based on the judgment of Vivian Bose, J.  as he then was , in Jainarayan Ramgopal Marwadi v. Balwant Maroti Shingore  A.I.R. 1939 Nag. 35 , which had been approved in later judgments of that court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: TPA s.54 exhaustive on sales requiring registration for title transfer; governs transfers in Berar overriding any wider local interpretation.

holdings.text: TPA s.54 overrides Mohammedan law on transfers of immovable property.

anchor.surface_text: According to s. 2 of the Transfer of Property Act which at the relevant time was in operation in Berar s. 54 is one of the sections which ch. 2 of that Act and therefore it overrides Mohammedan law and the provision of that section, being exhaustive as to modes of transfer, govern all sales in that province

holdings.reasoning_summary: TPA s.2 specifies Ch.2 sections including s.54 override personal laws like Mohammedan law in areas of application.

holdings.text: Delaying execution of registered sale deed to avoid pre-emption is not fraud as pre-emption is a weak right defeasible by legitimate means.

anchor.surface_text: It was next contended that the appellant was guilty of fraud in that in order to defeat the right of the pre-emptors a deed of sale was not executed although as a matter of fact price had been paid, possession had passed and for all intents and purposes the appellant had become the owner of the property

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-emption right arises only post-transfer; parties may lawfully complete transfer after suit; follows precedents like Bishan Singh.

holdings.text: The suit was premature as it was based on contracts of April 1943, not the sale deed of February 1944, creating no enforceable pre-emption right.

anchor.surface_text: It was then submitted that the sale deed had as a matter of fact, been executed on February 1, 1944 but respondent Sridhar brought the suit not on the cause of action arising on the sale dated February 1, 1944, but on the transaction of April 10, 1943

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cause of action arises only on registered sale; contracts confer no interest; premature suit prevents defenses like land diversion.

holdings.text: Transfer of immovable property worth Rs.100+ requires registration under Registration Act ss.17,49; unregistered documents ineffective.

anchor.surface_text: Section 17 read with s. 49 of the Registration Act shows that a transfer of immoveable property where it is worth Rs. 100 or more requires registration and unless so registered the document does not affect the property

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supports TPA s.54; no title passes without registration; quoted Mahmood J. on consequences.

holdings.text: The right of pre-emption is weak, not favored by courts, and can be defeated by lawful means without equities for pre-emptor.

anchor.surface_text: The right to pre-empt the sale is not exercisable till a pre-emptible transfer has been effected and the right of pre-emption is not one which is looked upon with great favour by the courts presumably for the reason that it is in derogation of the right of the owner to alienate his property.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derogation of alienation right; courts disfavor; affirmed by precedents including own court's Bishan Singh.

precedents.cited_holding: If a valid and perfected sale were not a condition precedent to the exercise of the pre-emptive right, consequences would follow which the law of pre-emption does not contemplate

precedents.cited_holding: The right being a very weak right, it can be defeated by all legitimate methods, such as the vendee allowing the claimant of a superior or equal right being substituted in his place

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the word sale in s. 176 of the Code had a wider connotation than what it had under s. 54 of the Transfer of Property Act. That was based on the judgment of Vivian Bose, J.  as he then was , in Jainarayan Ramgopal Marwadi v. Balwant Maroti Shingore  A.I.R. 1939 Nag. 35 , which had been approved in later judgments of that court.
